description:
Arthrobacter woluwensis is a species of bacteria that belongs to the genus Arthrobacter. It is a Gram-positive, non-spore-forming, aerobic bacterium known for its ability to thrive in diverse environmental conditions.

Arthrobacter woluwensis was first isolated from soil samples collected in Woluwe-Saint-Lambert, Belgium. It is a coccoid-shaped bacterium that exhibits a characteristic morphological transition during its life cycle, changing from a coccoid form to a rod-shaped form.

This species is known to be capable of degrading a variety of organic compounds, including hydrocarbons and aromatic compounds, which makes it a potential candidate for bioremediation applications. Arthrobacter woluwensis has also been studied for its ability to produce biosurfactants, which can enhance the solubility and bioavailability of hydrophobic compounds.

Taxonomically, Arthrobacter woluwensis is classified within the phylum Actinobacteria and the family Micrococcaceae. It is closely related to other Arthrobacter species and shares similarities in its physiological and biochemical characteristics.
